snippet: The referendum asked voters whether Michigan should retain a law that allowed the governor to appoint “emergency managers” with broad oversight of financial decisions for struggling local governments.
abstract: Several of Michigan's most financially distressed cities are engulfed in uncertainty after voters strike down law that gave state-appointed officials sweeping authority to make decisions for those communities; law was intended to help municipalities avoid bankruptcy or default, but had been criticized for infringing on rights of local governments.
lead_paragraph: The referendum asked voters whether Michigan should retain a law that allowed the governor to appoint “emergency managers” with broad oversight of financial decisions for struggling local governments.

headline.seo: Michigan Voters Kill ‘Emergency Managers’ for City Finances
headline.main: Michigan Voters Repeal a Financial Law
headline.print_headline: Michigan Voters Repeal a Financial Law
